review_title: Serious problems, but worth it for some
pros: Beautiful campus and buildings. Access to interesting cultural events. Quality museum that brings in world-class artists. Some opportunity for travel. Kind and passionate coworkers. Occasional free food at some meetings. Discounts at the school cafeteria (the food is surprisingly good!). Free access to gym and gym classes. Free tuition and discount on taxes for classes. Good medical benefits. 3% 401K matching. Staff workshops+coaches to help with public speaking. PTO got to be nice after you had been there a few years. Free adoption assistance and retirement planning. Work/life balance was good, in that my supervisors always encouraged me to take lunch breaks and leave on time whenever possible.
cons: Kind of feel bad rating it a 2 and not a 3, because there really are some nice perks that I appreciated. But, the negatives are significant. Most people I know who left share that they are working through the impacts of having been employed by SCAD years several later. The gaslighting, culture of fear, and belittlement takes a psychological toll on you, and you leave with some unpacking and unlearning to process. They want to pay you as little as possible and will take advantage of the fact that most staff are younger, don't have much other experience, and don't know how a good organization should treat them. They will discourage you from discussing salary with coworkers, even though federal labor law protects this. If you mention average rates for your role in this industry, they will gaslight you and try to convince you of why you are not worthy. Politics are out of hand. There is a culture of fear that management benefits from. People who have been loyal for years, who have been SCAD's biggest advocates, are fired without warning for no known reason. Staff are scared that they could lose their jobs for reasons beyond their control, and many aim for perfection in what they do because of a fear of losing their jobs if they make a minor mistake. (This rarely actually happens, though.) A focus on perfection may help you keep the job, but it will not help you get ahead. The quality or quantity of your work does not matter in this regard. Your ambition and passion are irrelevant. What gets you ahead is how big of a show you put on in front of people in power. Talking yourself up in front of higher ups and making them feel powerful will get you ahead. If the hard numbers show that you are not an effective leader, this can be brushed off easily if you are one of the "golden" people. This is not ideal for those who don't have a tendency to brag or be insincere/manipulative, but want to actually get work done and take pride in it. There are exceptions, but I saw this too often to not make note of it. The focus on appearances was also noteworthy. 90% of student facing roles went to younger staff who are above average in attractiveness and have an on-brand sense of style. There was a lack of diversity in how we look--not in race, but in body type, age, style, and attractiveness. We realized that this was part of their marketing efforts towards students, and it felt objectifying. I have also not seen any women in leadership positions who do not get regular manicures, put on makeup, and wear heals. Women received positive reinforcement for doing these things. Yes, you need to put in effort into your appearance anywhere and look polished--but it felt like too much value was placed on these specific aspects of a women's appearance. (It wasn't policy, just something I saw.) The Covid policy left many staff feeling unsafe, especially those made to return to work in an open work space. These are loud and people are close together. Studies have shown that these layouts do not benefit employees, but SCAD uses them throughout its buildings. Hopefully this changes soon. There is a saying that "eyes are everywhere". If you go to a bar and see a student or someone in HR, the unwritten rule is that you must leave immediately. Staff are afraid to have a social life in public spaces, least someone see you and misinterpret what you are doing. People do not feel comfortable speaking their mind about SCAD, even when they are off-campus and outside of work hours. I cannot count the number of times a coworker has glanced around the room fearfully to see if anyone they recognized from SCAD was nearby, before speaking their mind--while in a non-SCAD location on a weekend. Being cautious is smart, but the extent of their fear was unusual. Meanwhile, there are staff that have been known to have inappropriate relations with students who have been protected due to politics. This isn't gossip--these staff members openly and proudly told others of their relations with students. There is a very strange double standard. Rules for regular staff to not apply to the "golden" people, but I think they should.

SCAD could be a fantastic place to work if the family would only share some of the success with the people working there. Potential students understand that your extraordinary faculty are being driven by a family of leaders that are difficult to work with and do not share the success or wealth of the success. SCAD did it all, not the faculty, no names, only the school's identity. The family takes credit for the outstanding faculty. It is challenging to find pros without the overshadowing cons of this university while working there.
cons:
SCAD senior management runs the school under fear. Do it their way, or you are out. We are better than everyone. The reviews (fake reviews) are lying. Look over here at how pretty we are. If someone beats SCAD in a review, then there must be a problem with the fake news. Hire performers and have big parties to make ourselves seem important. Take pretty pictures and Photoshop them to make them look perfect. Almost as ignorant as holding a press conference in front of gold elevators.

Senior management will continually ask to make the departments bigger “Yuuuuge” with no understanding of quality or sustainability. I was asked by senior MGT: how can we make it bigger? Me: We are 5 times the size or more of our top-tier competitors. Senior MGT: We are better than all of them. Me: With all due respect, there are some good options out there School A does this and School B does this… I was cut off. Senior MGT: Don’t ever say that again. We can learn nothing from them. We are better. If someone wants to study anything art-related, they should come to SCAD, not there. You really need to stop talking about any other schools you are at SCAD now.

Although their approach to immigrants is different than Trumps. They will gladly take them if they can pay the tuition. SCAD has majors for everything possible, even those with minimal job opportunities. Minors for even more and more. Stay for your master’s degree too, as long as you can pay the tuition. New names and new restructures allow for more degrees and buzzwords, but will the students get jobs?

Me: With all the increases, we will need more faculty and support, plus additional space, resources, and computers. We are bursting at the seams, and the building is showing some wear. Faculty are really getting tired and overloaded. We must discuss a growth strategy with the faculty who use the space. Senior MGT: We are already looking into that and have some surprises for you. Focus on making the numbers increase.

As far as work hours go, you work all the time when the quarter is in session. Some people were teaching 5 to 6 courses a term just to cover the growth. You will be expected to answer immediately, no matter when the request comes in, depending on your responsibility. If you are a leader, then your expectations are 24/7. It is in your contract.

When the president arrives, and you will know when she is coming, the place will have people running around swarming like bees to prepare the space, so it is perfect for her arrival. You need to treat her like royalty. If you are allowed to speak with her, you are prepared beforehand and given guidance on what to say. She is not approachable or even interested in what your thoughts are. The process is to follow, with no exceptions. Leaders who accept this lifestyle are put in high positions to watch over the flocks of talented faculty. Good ones get tired and leave if they can. You work so hard throughout the year that it is challenging to look for work because you have no time. Faculty are on a one-year contract only. There is a small window out, and if you break your contract for whatever reason, you are hit with a 5K fee. Considering the faculty pay, this can be a big blow. HR will come after you with collections if you do not pay.

The school puts resources into showcasing itself very well, but it is not all for the students. Why does the school need a private jet? Why such expensive parties? Why bring in top-name singers to perform for the faculty at meetings? Celebrities flown in to be interviewed and put online for PR? “The family” is making so much money and the faculty are struggling to pay their bills and live in a safe part of town. It is not cheap to live in a “good” area of Savannah if you can find one.

Savannah is a depressed town set in a mentality of decades past. Major problems include a high level of racism, poverty, and extremely high crime. Faculty tell stories of gunshots, robberies, held at gunpoint, attacks, and other horrific stories. It is not a safe place. It is not a place for families. The public schools are run down, punitive, and so lousy faculty tell stories of their children crying about how terrible they are. The charter and specialty schools are not much better. Don’t be fooled by the Savannah locals (fake news) who think the schools are excellent. Some of them have never left Savannah and are not aware of modern approaches to teaching even exist. Private is the only option. Just ask the SCAD Leaders where their kids go. When these concerns are brought up to the Senior MGT or HR you are told: Don’t bring this up again.

SCAD is a machine controlled by the top. There is no room for ideas unless they come from the family or are proven to increase student numbers. No sharing of the wealth. No distribution of money down to the faculty or Staff who are making the school strong through guiding the students. The school looks happy and healthy in the pictures online, during visits, and even during short stays. It is far from a healthy work environment.

job_title: Director of Curriculum Management in Savannah, GA
pros: There are a lot of good people at SCAD. I admired and respected many of my coworkers and developed strong personal and professional bonds with colleagues in many departments and disciplines. Leaving those friendships behind was the most difficult part of my decision to leave my position with the university.
cons:
I came to SCAD excited to be part of an innovative, creative, and energized community centered on preparing students to excel in creative fields. I yearned to make a meaningful contribution to my team in these efforts; yet, the occasions when I felt that my contributions were welcomed or meaningful were extremely limited by a controlling and critical administration. In the eyes of the leadership of my department, I seemed to be most useful at performing rote tasks like formatting documents, organizing files, and producing repetitive reports that required no creative or critical thought -- in spite of having two master’s degrees and over a decade of experience in higher education, most of that experience at an art and design college.
 
When I was promoted to a director-level role in my department, I believed I would finally have the opportunity to draw from the skills and experiences I had cultivated through my own education and career to make meaningful improvements to processes that had become cumbersome and outdated. I had worked hard to build rapport with faculty and academic leadership, and I thought I could build consensus through transparency and clear communication of policies and procedures. Sadly, the opposite was true. All planning and decision making took place at the executive-level, often without consulting me about actions that would directly impact not only myself and my staff, but the university as a whole. I spent my time, including many late nights and most weekends, transferring other people’s work into the correct formats and then refereeing the conflicts created between faculty and administration due to lack of communication. Every day, people were angry with me about decisions that I had no control over, and I received little support or even consideration from the people responsible for the decisions that eroded the rapport I had worked so hard to build over the years. I often had to reverse prior communications regarding deadlines, timelines, and policies because the authority of my position was meaningless when it created any inconvenience for upper administration. 

In short, SCAD has a leadership problem. Upper administration neglects the professional development of employees with significant experience and potential by reducing them to meaningless data entry or clerical responsibilities. They create an environment that is professionally discouraging through derisively criticizing others’ work, failing to recognize contributions and accomplishments of all but a select group of favorite team members, and showing no awareness of the struggles or aspirations of their employees. While they tout collaboration as a key university value, in reality they are seeking enthusiastic conformity and compliance with the wishes of the administration. They are motivated by fear of losing their own power or position and engage in bullying, cut-throat competition, and in-fighting at the cost of the employees who produce the work that makes them successful. 

If you value your own career and professional development and if you want to be valued as part of a team effort, be very cautious in accepting a position at SCAD. If you are content to draw a good paycheck while you follow orders without question and give unconditional accolades to an administration driven by a quest for power, money, and recognition (as opposed to student learning, employee well-being, and academic freedom), it could be a fine fit for you.

pros:

For the most part, the people you work with are great, but won't last long because they are mistreated.

Most students are lovely. They are what makes working there tolerable.
cons:
There is absolutely no work-life balance at SCAD. They target recent college graduates and aim to suck them dry and show them the door. Most employees last less than a year. I often work 60-80 hour weeks with no overtime pay, and I was given a salary that I couldn't survive on if it wasn't for my spouse's income. They will grossly misrepresent the hours that you will work during the interview process. I was told "occasional weekends" were required and I work every single holiday weekend and usually 2-3 normal weekends monthly, which is miserable. 

Human Resources chooses who gets promoted and managers have very little say-- keep in mind that Human Resources never actually sees the work that you do. For that matter, there are very few places to move upward for employees. The attitude is that they suck you dry and show you the door. It's a very discouraging place to work, and 90% of my coworkers have one foot out the door. Usually I'm enthusiastic and optimistic, but I've lost any hope that SCAD will do right by me.

There's a standard 3% raise each year to cover inflation, and you get that whether you're an overachiever or an underachiever, although they try to paint is as a "performance based" incentive.

I would say if you've just graduated college and want to build up your resume, it's worth suffering though for a year or two. If you're looking for a long-term position with a company that values your contributions, look elsewhere. Ask very specific questions during your interview if you choose to pursue employment with SCAD, and trust your gut. Human Resources is widely known to misrepresent and blatantly lie about a number of positions, especially those in the Admission department.

review_title: So Much Potential Squandered -- Very Negative Environment
pros:
SCAD attracts some very talented, driven and ambitious students, as well as a large number of unbelievably well-qualified, talented and dedicated faculty and staff -- all of whom are a joy to work with and around, especially if you enjoy a creative academic environment.  

The city of Savannah itself is also a considerable draw: the historic district is picturesque and welcoming; it's a small city with a fairly reasonable cost of living; has a burgeoning arts and culture scene; and the weather is temperate 9 months out of the year.
cons:
The cons are many, unfortunately:

The worst is the pervasive culture of fear and intimidation. It is, without question, the most toxic environment that I have ever worked in, in over 25+ years. Literally everyone lives in constant fear of being fired at any moment, without warning -- it doesn't matter how smart you are, how dedicated or how successful in your role or area of expertise.

The vast majority of upper level management are not qualified for the positions that they hold and are in their positions only because of their personal relationship to the president of the college or a member of her immediate family, all of whom hold executive level positions. Their incompetence creates a horrible ripple effect of unnecessary problems and issues for the college as a whole and for those in middle management and below, who actually are qualified and are working tirelessly to do their best for the benefit of the students and their co-workers.

In fact, the more successful one is in their role, the more they have to fear. Executive and upper management does not want to be challenged or held to the universally accepted standards for institutions of higher learning. Management is more interested in blindly-loyal foot soldiers than in innovative, qualified and (gasp!) confident administrators or faculty. People who suggest ways to improve, who strive for best-practices, or push for transparency are shown the door and quickly.

The work/life balance is exceptionally unhealthy. Staff and faculty are expected to work 50-60 hours a week routinely and even longer hours at several busier times throughout the year. You are expected to have no other interests or activities outside of SCAD. Additionally, if management can figure out how to turn your side passion or freelance successes into something that benefits SCAD, they will lean on you, hard, to do so.  

Although starting pay is often better than other area entry level positions, the regular raises and performance/merit  incentives promised during the interview process, rarely if ever materialize. It is not uncommon to be told that if you hit certain benchmarks that you will receive an increase in pay, only to have the benchmark moved up just before you reach it, or to be told that your supervisor has no recollection of ever having promised you an increase.

Employee turn-over is incredibly high, which is discouraging for those left behind. Intelligent, competent and talented staff and faculty would often get frustrated by the horrible work environment, the broken promises, the pressure to behave unethically, the horrendous expectations regarding working hours, the lack of academic integrity, the focus on appearances above substance, and their pay being "capped" or being ineligible for raises due to constantly moving targets. The constant change of staff and faculty makes it difficult to maintain a stable and productive work place.

Alumni and donor relations are both incredibly shallow and disingenuous; there is no interest from upper management in investing in these important relationships. Development staff was given inadequate resources and constantly dealt with unrealistic expectations. It was commonplace for fundraising events to be excuses to spend obscene amounts of money to throw a party, only concerned about the college's image and or PR opportunities, and not to actually earn any money towards the department, program or scholarships that it was meant to go to. By the time I left, management was actively lying to donors and misrepresenting where their donations were going and how their gifts were being used. 

When I first started working at SCAD the culture wasn't as ridiculous, damaging or negative as it was when I left. It was very sad and discouraging to watch the college deteriorate over the years, rotting from the inside-out, due to the gross incompetence of management and the deep, deep paranoia that seems to drive everything that they do for the past decade. I held on for much too long, hoping to see it return to its original mission and to once again find its way, only to be disappointed that it continued to get worse and at a more rapid pace. The loss of several qualified high-level leaders in the span of two/three years seemed to contribute to this acceleration; they were replaced by warm bodies loyal to the president and her son and incapable of advancing the college in a meaningful way. It really is a shame -- there was so much potential that has been squandered.

review_title: Wonderful students, talented professors...exploited by toxic administration
pros: Passionate students, freedom to be creative in designing courses, helpful colleagues
cons:
1. Students are asked to pay an incredible amount of money for tuition, room, and board, and SCAD can't be bothered to give back to them. To wit, the food in the Hive cafe literally looks like it was gathered from a dumpster. Really. There is an entire Instagram account dedicated to it.
2. Upper management isn't connected to the needs or concerns of faculty, staff, or students. They're concern is with branding, profit, and developing SCAD...but in the way that a fast food franchise would be obsessed with opening new locations.
3. There are layers and layers of needless middle management and people are shifted between jobs, sometimes for no logical reason. People often end up in jobs that they are, through no fault of their own, not at all qualified for.
4. Profs are overworked and underpaid. But, really, that's true everywhere. What's awful about SCAD is that professors are seen as liabilities. They are people who need freedom and support to communicate with students openly and honestly about curriculum...but also about what it takes to become the sort of person they can be proud of. But admin fears academic freedom because it approaches the classroom the way corporate American would. Profs need to become PR people that will stay on message. As a result, academic freedom is non existent. Critical feedback--that could be used to help SCAD grow is stamped out. Faculty are micromanaged, infantilized, rarely praised, underpaid, and yet we are the reason SCAD is great. We protect students from all of the greed that is the ethos of upper management.
6. If you can stay out of admin's way, you'll have a decent experience...for awhile. But I've been straight up lied to so many times that I have to leave. The lies? About salary? About job prospects? About additional work I do that they "can't afford to pay." I loved the students and would have loved to stay, but the admin wears you down. It's tragic because SCAD has so much promise. Students realize it. They get sad about it. They hate it for us. They're not stupid. But if they really about all the ways they were exploited they would be shocked.
